document:
All night
in the brisk and shallow restlessness
of early spring
I think of her,

two strangers
who were,
it soon appeared,
not men at all,
but gods.
Oh, to love what is lovely, and will not last!

When this book ends
I will pull it inside-out like a sock
and throw it back in the library.
moon snails, pale pink and barnacle scarred—

Whoever named the place learned the hard lesson,
I'd guess, without much fanfare or delay.

we keep ourselves alive,
if we can, taking one after another
the necessary bodies of others, the many
crushed red flowers.

and for every person
the body glowing inside the clothes
like a light.

it needs the body's world,
instinct
and imagination
and the dark hug of time,

and to do this
I will go indoors to my desk --
I will sit in my chair --
I will look back
into the lost morning

we are risen, tangled together, certain to fall
back to the sea.

while everywhere I look on the scratchy hillsides
shadows seem to grow shoulders.

but still they asked for nothing
but the difficult life
which they had already.

No doubt he thought of everything
that had happened in his difficult life.

Every year
the lilies
are so perfect

I will look back
into the lost morning
in which I am moving, now,
like a swimmer,

I'd watch the face, how the mouth
has to work, and see any strain, any
sign of what lifted the voice.

and every pond,
no matter what its
name is, is
nameless now.
Then you begin, slowly, to read the whole story.
We hope for magic; mystery endures.

all day I think of her —
her white teeth,
her wordlessness,
her perfect love.

All summations have a beginning, all effect has a
story, all kindness begins with the sown seed.

Where, in what country, might I put down these thoughts,
Who still am citizen of this fallen city?

I think of this every morning
as the east begins
to tear off its many clouds
of darkness,

Every morning
the world
is created.

it is also this dazzling darkness
coming
down the mountain,
breathing and tasting;

An echo,
continuous from the title onward, hums
behind me.

I wake earlier, now that the birds have come
And sing in the unfailing trees.

Because, properly
attended to, delight, as well as havoc, is suggestion.

whatever it was I said
I would be doing—

to be more than pure light
that burns
where no one is --
Thought buds toward radiance.

I wake earlier, now that the birds have come
And sing in the unfailing trees.

And for all, I'd know more -- the earth
bracing itself and soaring,

Around him, the villagers gathered
and stretched forward to listen.
A candleflame in Tibet leans when I move.

we are risen, tangled together, certain to fall
back to the sea.

I thought the earth remembered me,
she took me back so tenderly,
arranging her dark skirts, her pockets
full of lichens and seeds.

All summations have a beginning, all effect has a
story, all kindness begins with the sown seed.
Oh, to love what is lovely, and will not last!

If I stopped and thought, maybe
the world
can’t be saved,
the pain
was unbearable.

and listen better to the wind
or to the air being still.

For myself, I find my wanting life
Implores no novelty and no disguise of distance;

You aren’t much, I said
one day to my reflection
in a green pond,
and grinned.

and I want
to live my life all over again, to begin again,
to be utterly
wild.
Thought buds toward radiance.
Oh, to love what is lovely, and will not last!

Today is a day like any other: twenty-four hours, a
little sunshine, a little rain.

I'd watch the face, how the mouth
has to work, and see any strain, any
sign of what lifted the voice.
Here or nowhere I will make peace with the fact.

If it is your nature
to be happy
you will swim away along the soft trails
for hours, your imagination
alighting everywhere.

By now the hawk has flown five miles
at least,
dazzling whoever else has happened
to look up.

I think of the blueberry fields, the blackberry tangles,
the cranberry bogs.

How long do they live, fluttering
in and out of the shadows?

I think of this every morning
as the east begins
to tear off its many clouds
of darkness,

whatever it was I said
I would be doing—
And did you see it, finally, just under the clouds --

All night
in the brisk and shallow restlessness
of early spring
I think of her,

It is dark in here, but the chapters open
their beautiful spaces and give a rustling sound,

like the rain pelting the trees, like a waterfall
nifing down the black ledges?

and after a while it rises and becomes a creature
like her, but much smaller.

Slowly, beneath the branches,
he raised his head.
He looked into the faces of that frightened crowd.

The first fish
I ever caught
would not lie down
quiet in the pail
but flailed and sucked
at the burning
amazement of the air

As for spiders, how the dew hangs in their webs
even if they say nothing, or seem to say nothing.

Surely
a beast might be clever, be lucky, move quietly
through the woods for years, learning to stay away
from roads and houses.

edged
with pine boughs and wet boulders,
pawprints of bobcat and bear,

The ants bore into the peony bud and there is a dark
pinprick well of sweetness.
A candleflame in Tibet leans when I move.

the air
finding every leaf and feather over
forest and water

On a cot by an open window
I lie like land used up, while spring unfolds.

until the white snow is written upon
in large, exuberant letters,

A perfect commotion of silk and linen as it leaned
into the bondage of its wings;

Surely
a beast might be clever, be lucky, move quietly
through the woods for years, learning to stay away
from roads and houses.

It offers me its busyness. It does not believe
that I do not want it.

the hard knife-edged love
for the warm river of the I, beyond all else;

The smell
is lurid and flows out in the most
unabashed way,

when they rose
out of their mortal bodies,
like a million particles of water
from a fountain,

attracting
into itself a continual spattering
of protein.

Oh, I could not have said it better
myself.

as we glide
Over the final jutting mountainside,
Across the suburbs tangled in their lights,

a white cross Streaming across the sky, its feet
like black leaves, its wings like the stretching light of the river?

and, being the color of snow, catching the sun
so they were, in part at least, golden.

all the dreams of my blood
and all outrageous divisions of time
seem ready to leave,
to slide out of me.

it was
a flock of snow geese, winging it
faster than the ones we usually see,

No doubt he thought of everything
that had happened in his difficult life.

and to do this
I will go indoors to my desk --
I will sit in my chair --
I will look back
into the lost morning

while everywhere I look on the scratchy hillsides
shadows seem to grow shoulders.

and the old couple,
shaken with understanding,
bowed down—

It doesn't have to be
the blue iris, it could be
weeds in a vacant lot, or a few
small stones;

As for spiders, how the dew hangs in their webs
even if they say nothing, or seem to say nothing.

Under the orange
sticks of the sun
the heaped
ashes of the night
turn into leaves again
and fasten themselves to the high branches --

so it enters us --
in the morning
shines from brute comfort
like a stitch of lightning;

Slowly, beneath the branches,
he raised his head.
He looked into the faces of that frightened crowd.

while all around me the lilies
are breaking open again
from the black cave
of the night.

When anyone talked to me, whether
blame or praise or just passing time,

Which is the only way to love, isn't it?
This isn't a playground, this is
earth, our heaven, for a while.

that it is more than the sum
of each flawed blossom rising and fading.
